recordings.rmk:
Haliaeetus albicilla?
The sound is very bad, with a lot of wind, but I think it is noticeable. I would add that Genneper Parken which is crossed by the Dommel River and its canals, has several areas of mudflats with reedbed and woods. It was heard in the High Tech Campus Eindhoven area.

This sound is no longer a mystery. Two days later I returned to the place and saw the bird that made this sound: a corvus corone.

recordings.loc: Batheaston, Bath and North East Somerset, England
recordings.rmk:
I have uploaded this recording as it includes odd calls at the beginning and from 2:02. This pair of crows were in a tree by the River Avon having a conversation. I don't know the meaning of the odd calls, and I couldn't see the birds in the tree, but I wonder if they are associated with a specific activity such as mating. Another curious sound is at 3:41 and sounds like it may be made with the beak.    

Recorded with an Olympus LS-12 and Sennheiser ME66 handheld. High pass filter added (150 Hz, 6dB) but still contains some vehicle noise and also some handling noise below 100 Hz. I deliberately kept the frequency of this filter low to not affect any of the birds' calls. There are some other deep sounds that I think are from one of the birds including one at 300 Hz at 0:14. 
The sound at 7:43 is a fish breaking the surface of the river, not a bird call!

Equipment: Olympus WS-822 digital recorder with Audio-technica ATR 6550 shotgun.

A group of carrion crows assembling in several spread out large trees in a park Landscape around sunset. This seems to be a pre-roosting place. Most of them were carrion crows, but there were also some rooks around, though they might not be on the recording. The crows were making a diverse collection of their usual calls, as well as quite a variety of more unusual calls, mostly quite short and quieter than the usual common calltype. I've been standing directly under one of the large trees with some of the crows sitting directly above me, where I pointed a Sennheiser ME67 shotgun microphone, and several other groups of crows in the sourrounding trees. Due to the trees beeing some distance away from each other and due to the directionality of the microphone, it can be heard in the recording which of the crows were calling from the tree where I was standing, and which called from other trees. It can be heard that often there's a long gap where no crow calls, but as soon as one of them starts calling several others immediately respond, usually those sitting in the same tree. Afterwards a long gap follows again. From time to time some of the crows changed trees and their wingsounds can be heard. Shortly after the recording they collectively flew away, presumably to their roost or another pre-roost.

GOSHAWK ALARM Before recording: Northern Goshawk (male?) flying straight through forest, just below treetops.  Recording: At least two Crows follow the path of Goshawk, above canopy, calling out loud. At the edge of the forest they are flying in circles, still calling, now less frantically.
